ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how sedimentary rocks are formed, and how stratigraphy can be interpreted.
Sed/Strat knowledge, fossils, depositional mechanisms, gravitational mechanisms, transport kinematics.

I learned principles in sedimentology: what processes shape Earth's environments and how these can be interpreted from the sedimentary record. The course covers both theoretical concepts and practical information for sedimentology fieldwork.
Everything I will ever need about sedimentary rocks and stratigraphy. Honestly I learned the most I have at Yale in this class it is very content heavy.
I learned so much! I've come out of this class knowing so much more about how the world works. It seems like there is nothing this class doesn't touch on. Just amazing.
I learned a lot about sedimentary processes and environments, and some about stratigraphy.

I learned so much about sedimentary rocks, depositional processes, fossils, paleoclimatology and more. Since you have to talk about a wide range of subjects in order to talk about sedimentary rocks, etc., I learned so so much about a wide range of geological subjects, from atmospheric science to fossilization to oceanography to weathering. I also got hands-on experience working with sedimentary rocks.
The course offered an information-rich overview of stratigraphy and sedimentology, including theoretical principles, common physical environments, and relevant experimental methods.

Knowledge: sedimentary rocks and patterns in how they are created!
Skills: interpretation of depositional environment based on what we see in a sedimentary rock.
Insights: sedimentary rocks are cool windows to the past.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - Lidya is a great instructor. She gives lots of feedback in a timely fashion. There are extra credit opportunities. The labs are very cool, and make use of samples loaned from the Peabody.
Weaknesses - no field trip :(

This course is extremely well-organized and teaches a thorough overview of sedimentation. The labs provide excellent application of learned concepts, and the instruction is clear and accessible. There should be more labs, and perhaps field experiences. Additionally, the quizzes added more stress than opportunity for retention.

Strengths: The course was very well organized and followed a clear trajectory. I appreciated how closely it followed the textbook, too. The two hands-on labs were fun and useful for learning to apply our knowledge to interpreting hand samples. Guest lectures were very relevant and effective.
Weaknesses: Prof Tarhan's lecture style is long-winded and my classmates and I were often confused about very simple concepts due to her roundabout explanations and unclear answers to questions. Also, there really are pop quizzes, so people were kind of anxious about the class all the time. I think it would have been more effective to have a scheduled quiz every week or two.

I think the pop quizzes could create a really stressful learning environment at times, but I do think the quizzes were the reason I learned/studied so much in this class. Come the midterm, I felt really prepared. Since they were so frequent I think the quizzes would have had the same effect even if we had warning though. 
Also I feel like the textbook did not really mirror the class and could be optional.

There are really only strengths. The class is expertly taught, the assignments do a great job of helping to better understand the material, and grading is very fair. I would take the class again in an instant. The one weakness was the pop quizzes. I think having scheduled weekly quizzes would have all the benefits of regular testing but without the stress of them being a surprise each time.

Lidya's lectures are very information dense, which can be a pro or a con depending on how well you can keep up. We covered about 1 chapter of the textbook per class, and with each chapter being 20-40 pages long it was a lot of material to get through.

It was nice not having psets or any other type of regular homework assignments, but we did have pop quizzes so the expectation was that we should always be studying. I understand the justification, but it also caused a lot of unnecessary anxiety, so it'd be nice to have scheduled quizzes.

Lidya is a very organized professor, which is both a strength in that it means she stays on schedule and you know what youre supposed to be learning and a weakness in that it means her powerpoints are sparse on words yet she says a lot in class so its hard to write it all down. We had pop quizzes which were a major weakness of the course. They stressed students out to no end and there was no way to prepare accommodations for them as we would not know if they were happening until she walked into class with papers. It would have been much more beneficial to do weekly quizzes on one day than pop quizzes scattered about.

Strengths: Super organized, you learn so much, the grading is really spaced out across lots of different types of assignments, and Lidya is so passionate and engaging. I looked forward to this class every week.

Weaknesses: Although the level of detail that we went into was really interesting, I do think that at times it distracted me from learning about the key themes in the course. I think cutting some detail and emphasizing major concepts instead would be great.

The course covers a lot of interesting content. This is mostly a good thing, but it also sometimes meant that we were moving so fast through the material that it felt a bit hard to actually comprehend it, rather than just memorize it. I think that in some instances, structuring the lectures around real-world examples/anecdotes (rather than purely abstract method/theory) would have made them more easily comprehensible. It was also not always the easiest to participate in such a sizable lecture-based class, which I feel made it a little difficult to satisfy the participation requirement of the grade. 

Again, though, a very interesting class! I certainly learned a lot.

Strengths: awesome professor, very thorough
Weaknesses: jargon-heavy, sometimes hard to keep up in lecture
How it could be improved: publish the lecture notes in Canvas BEFORE the class so I can better keep up with the lecture as it's going

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this has been one of my favorite classes at Yale. Clear, timely feedback, interesting topics, fun labs.
Yes! Professor Tarhan is excellent and her syllabus provides a wonderful overview of sed/strat. This class is the only class at Yale that discusses sed/strat and it is very helpful

Although I learned a lot from this course, I would not necessarily recommend it. There is a lot of memorization that didn't feel worth it (for example, we had to memorize an entire classification scheme that could easily be referenced in the field). While the overall topics are relevant and important, the majority of the time I spent on this class was learning things too niche to even be necessary for fieldwork. It certainly depends on your background and goals, but if I could do it again I might not take this class.
Yes to other EPS majors, but only if the pop quizzes are something that does not give you that kind of anxiety.
Yes one million times. This is one of my favorite classes I have taken at Yale. Lidya is a total gem and the material is so interesting.
Yes, its good knowledge for EPS majors.
If you are interested in the rock record, paleoclimates, fossils, etc. this is a great class.
Yes. It's a fairly high workload, but if for any reason you are looking for an introduction to the sedimentary rock record, this will give you that.
Yes! It was simply so good and well-taught and the professor clearly cares about her students so much and the content was very interesting.
